name: False Dilemma
definition: Presenting only two options when more exist.
whyItWorks: Binary choices feel decisive and clear. By eliminating the messy middle ground, we force people to pick a side—often by making the other option sound terrible.

examples.text: Either you're always available to hang out, or you're not really my friend.
examples.analysis: Friendship isn't all-or-nothing. You can be a good friend and still have boundaries, other commitments, or need alone time.

examples.text: Either your parents trust you completely with your phone, or they're controlling and don't respect you.
examples.analysis: There are lots of middle grounds: check-ins, gradual freedom, agreed-upon limits. Trust isn't binary.

examples.text: You either support mass deportation or you want open borders. There's no in-between.
examples.analysis: There are lots of options between these two extremes that get ignored.

examples.text: America has to choose: be tough on crime, or coddle criminals and accept chaos.
examples.analysis: Ignores approaches that reduce crime AND treat people fairly—they're not mutually exclusive.

examples.text: Young people either need to work harder and stop complaining, or admit they want everything handed to them.
examples.analysis: Ignores that both personal effort AND bigger economic forces can matter at the same time.

promptStarters: You either ___ or ___. There's no middle ground.
It's simple: either we ___ or we accept ___.
You can't have it both ways—it's ___ or ___.
